Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2 - Reconstructing rates and sources of sea-level change over the last ~150 thousand years from a new coral database
Award.AbstractNarration:
COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: RECONSTRUCTING RATES AND SOURCES OF SEA LEVEL CHANGE OVER THE LAST ~150 THOUSAND YEARS FROM A NEW CORAL DATABASE

Future sea level rise, driven by shrinking land ice and ocean warming, threatens coastal populations, economic activity, infrastructure, and ecosystems around the world. Data on past sea level positions are critical for understanding how sensitive sea level and ice sheets are to temperature change. Paleo-sea level records come from several different sources. For time periods older than about 4000 years, some of the records with the best vertical resolution and most precise ages come from coral reefs, which grow at distinctive elevation ranges with respect to mean sea level.

During the Last Interglacial stage, about 125,000 years ago, global average sea-surface temperature peaked around its current level, while analyses of corals and other proxies indicate global mean sea level peaked about 6-9 m higher than today. This magnitude of sea level rise - implying considerably smaller ice sheets in Greenland and West Antarctica - hints at the long-term commitment current warming has imparted to future sea level rise. The researchers in this project will use the coral sea level database to better understand rates of sea level and ice-sheet change over time, and how these rates relate to changes in the global climate. The knowledge gained will contribute to work by this team and others in the research community on future sea level projections. The project will provide a graduate student and a postdoctoral researcher with interdisciplinary training in oceanography, geology, geophysics and statistics. It will also synthesize a global reconstruction of sea-level over the last 150,000 years, and associated numerical methods for producing this reconstruction, that can be broadly used by the research community.

This project focuses on four basic questions: (1) How much did global mean sea level vary over time, and how do local, relative sea levels vary in space, over this time period? (2) How fast did global mean sea level change during the last 150,000 years, and what was the relationship between changes in sea level and changes in temperature? (3) Can the spatial patterns of sea level change be used to separate the contributions of different ice sheets to global mean sea level change? (4) How does global mean sea level reconstructed using corals compare to other continuous records of sea level and climate change? To address these questions, the researchers will: (1) develop emulators of geophysical models of glacio-isostatic adjustment and mantle dynamic topography in order to estimate the contribution of different ice sheets to sea level change, (2) refine the history of seawater uranium isotope compositions that are important to interpreting accurate ages from U-Th-dated corals, and (3) incorporate ecological data about the relationship between coral growth position and sea level into a spatio-temporal statistical framework that links together the coral database and the geophysical models. The application of these techniques to the coral database for the last 150,000 years will provide a uniquely high-precision, continuous record of global mean sea level variability over this time period. This reconstruction will enable a more precise estimate of the magnitude of global mean sea level variability and rates of global mean sea level change, and should allow discrimination between global mean sea level contributions from North American and Arctic sources and those from Antarctic sources. These reconstructions will provide data with which to test the ice sheet models used to project future changes in addition to supporting the career development of a postdoctoral scholar and the training of a Ph.D. student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since instrumental measurements from tide gauges (and, more recently, satellites) can only be used to estimate sea level over the past 2-3 centuries at most, geological data must be used as proxies for sea level. This project developed an updated, internally consistent database of natural geological archives that reflect past sea levels and rates of sea-level change over the last 150,000 years. It also developed an advanced statistical model to interpret paleo-sea level data and estimate sea-level change over time and space. Different geophysical simulations, used in conjunction with the statistical model, allow testing of alternative histories regarding the timing and extent of ice growth and melt and Earth's response to these changes.

Estimates of sea level during the Last Interglacial (LIG, ~129,000 to 116,000 years ago) have been used to calibrate models of future ice-sheet changes because they represent the warmest interval in Earth history prior to the 21st century. However, past data from the LIG have many limitations, including large uncertainties, inconsistent dating, and, for some proxies, the commingling of sea level with other climate variables. Past statistical models also have limitations, such as the use of unreliable techniques like simple averages, bias toward dominant locations with more data, and inaccurate characterization of the relationship between observed geological features and sea level. These limitations affect the assessment of global mean sea level (GMSL) during the LIG, which in turn impacts inferences about the sensitivity of ice and sea level to rapid changes in climate during past warm periods.  Using the updated compilation of LIG data to test alternative ice-melt scenarios with different timing and contributions from Greenland, Antarctica and the Laurentide ice sheet can improve projections of future GMSL change, because ice sheets contribute the most sea-level uncertainty to estimates of future rise.

This grant has also contributed to statistical analyses of paleo-sea level data from other time periods.  Starting from the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM), this grant explored data from the Last Deglaciation (spanning from ~20,000 to 6,000 years ago), the Holocene (from ~12,000 years ago to present), the late Holocene (~5,000 years ago to present), and the Common Era (the last 2000 years).  Ashe et al. (2019) review the modeling and analysis choices available for various data, time periods, and scientific questions. A special issue in Quaternary Science Reviews included eleven publications presenting a global atlas of standardized sea-level records from the post-LGM.  This comprehensive database was inspired by the working group HOLSEA (Geographic variability of HOLocene relative SEA level), to which this grant contributed. Several other analyses of different locations (e.g., South Florida and eastern Canadian coastline) during these more recent periods resulted in new insight into the processes affecting sea level over years, centuries, and millennia. Development of a new statistical framework based on modern depth distributions of coral results in more realistic estimates of sea level. This new framework shows lower bias, greater precision, and better model fit than alternative approaches. This grant also contributed to a site-specific analysis of sea level along the U.S. Atlantic coast during the Common Era, which found an increasing influence of the global sea-level processes (e.g., ice melt and thermal expansion) since 1800 CE.
